awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research Award: Recycling of Material Culture
awd_abstract_narration:
Human reuse of space and material culture is a widely documented behavior throughout history, but researchers are only beginning to understand how recycling influenced human behavioral evolution. Recycling can take place either within an individual lifetime or at much larger time scales. Archaeology is therefore well positioned to examine the effects of recycling because the material culture record results from multiple activities and occupations over extended periods of time. It has been shown that recycling repeatedly rewrites archaeological patterns through history, yet researchers have limited models for studying its effects on the archaeological record. This project will investigate early examples of recycling, specifically that of stone tools. Models of previously unexplored factors that impact the frequency of recycling in archaeological deposits, allowing archaeologists to better understand why this behavior happens in certain locations will be developed. These will be employed to evaluate the temporal and spatial distributions of occupations in artifact deposits exposed on open land surfaces. Such sites constitute a major untapped source of information about the prehistory in a region, which has been a nexus of human movement and interaction. This project will also promote open science through sharing of computer code and archaeological data to facilitate reproducibility and accessibility. Furthermore, this project will foster international collaboration to make the archaeology more accessible so it can be better incorporated into the story of human history.   

It is currently argued that stone tool recycling occurred because of limited access to raw material sources. However, there are ethnographic and archaeological examples of recycling occurring in places with locally available stone resources. This project tests an updated model of recycling that is patterned by exposure of artifacts, selection behaviors, and mobility patterns. The investigators create agent-based computer simulations to identify artifact distributions that result from this proposed model. These patterns will then be compared to archaeological data from a Paleolithic surface site complex. It will be determined if concentrations of recycled objects overlap with proxies for exposure, selection, and mobility as patterned in the simulation. The models developed will help archaeologists identify parameters that make recycling more or less likely within a landscape, allowing for better understanding the history of human land use. This project represents an important step to explore the range of conditions that may promote recycling of stone tools in order to fully understand how this behavior functioned in the past.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Human reuse of space and material culture is a widely documented behavior throughout history. However, stone tool recycling, despite its documentation since the earliest manufacture of stone tools, often plays only an ancillary role in interpreting the archaeological record. This is problematic because recycling can significantly alter the temporal span and appearance of archaeological assemblages as it combines behaviors across time at multiple scales. Consequently, it is important to develop robust models for understanding how recycling impacts the formation of the archaeological record. This project used computer simulations and data from Paleolithic surface deposits in Kazakhstan to examine what types of behaviors and natural processes influence the prevalence of recycled objects in a landscape and how recycling behaviors affect the formation of the archaeological record through time. The results of this project provide a framework for accurately interpreting an archaeological record that emerges in the context of stone tool recycling.

 

The results of this project demonstrate that recycling is closely tied to the exposure of artifacts, with recycling occuring most frequently on artifacts that are discarded earlier in time. Additionally, the high rates of recycled artifacts from the surface deposits in Kazakhstan support the hypothesis that surface contexts, where artifacts are constantly exposed, would have been important locations for recycling behaviors given the ease of discovering and scavenging artifacts at these locations. Because of this, it is likely that recycling happened frequently in regions characterized by surface deposits of artifacts throughout prehistory. In these types of contexts, results from agent-based computer simulations of recycling behaviors demonstrate that mobility strategies and selection decisions when scavenging artifacts influence the number of recycled artifacts present on a landscape, and also change the relationships between the number of recycled artifacts and other archaeological metrics, like assemblage density and cortex ratios. Another important finding from the simulations is that concentrations of recycled artifacts often occur in different locations than where occupational behaviors such as stone tool manufacture or even stone tool scavenging frequently happen. Furthermore, in the context of frequent recycling behaviors, the number of recycled artifacts in any given archaeological deposit is highly variable. These results mean that trying to identify the importance of stone tool recycling based on the data from a single site will likely produce a biased view. Instead, recycling behaviors must be considered within the context of the wider landscape.

 

The archaeological record is a palimpsest of palimpsests, the outcome of many individual actions through time on scales beyond the lifetime of any single person. The findings that resulted from this project demonstrate that the archaeological record must be considered as the emergent product of prehistory and history that it is. This project is an important first step in exploring the many factors impacting the appearance of recycled artifacts in the archaeological record. This project is also a model for how to thoroughly investigate stone tool recycling in an archaeological context, both at the landscape level and at the artifactual level. Future studies of stone tool recycling can build on the findings of this project to continue aiding archaeologists in our quest to accurately interpret the archaeological record.

 

The results of this research have been disseminated through the submission of multiple articles to academic journals, one of which has already been published. The work from this project is also included in the PhD dissertation of the co-PI, whose degree was conferred in January 2024. The results from the archaeological fieldwork have been presented at multiple academic conferences, including one in Kazakhstan, where the fieldwork for this project was performed. All published material has been made and will be made publicly accessible through the Open Science Framework and GitHub. This means that future research can use the data and code from this project to answer new research questions.


Last Modified: 02/05/2024
Modified by: Emily Coco
